question: How do I determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for my oil well operations to decide whether I need to report emissions from completions and workovers of oil wells with hydraulic fracturing?
answer: To determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for oil well operations and decide whether emissions from completions and workovers of oil wells with hydraulic fracturing need to be reported, the GOR must be calculated for each well where associated natural gas is vented or flared. If the GOR for each well is not available, the GOR from a cluster of wells in the sub-basin can be used. The average GOR of all wells in thousand standard cubic feet per barrel must be reported. Additionally, if completions with hydraulic fracturing have a GOR of 300 scf/STB or greater, the average gas to oil ratio in standard cubic feet of gas per barrel of oil must be calculated and reported. The volume of oil produced during the time periods in which associated gas was vented or flared should also be reported. It is important to ensure accurate measurement and reporting of the GOR to comply with the regulations.

question: How should a gathering and boosting facility that previously reporting under Subpart C report in RY2016?
answer: In RY2016, a gathering and boosting facility that was previously reporting under Subpart C must now report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from various source types such as natural gas pneumatic device venting, equipment leaks, storage tanks, loading operations, delayed coking units, and uncontrolled blowdown systems. Additionally, the facility must calculate both CH4 and CO2 emissions from reciprocating compressor venting using Equation W–29D of this section. Therefore, the facility is required to report under Subpart W for onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting operations.

truth: Gathering and boosting segment facilities that previously reported their stationary combustion emissions under Subpart C for RY2015 and previous years must report their stationary combustion emissions under Subpart W beginning in RY2016 (reports due March 31, 2017) and going forward.Beginning in 2016, facilities that meet the definition of the new Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting segment (aka “gathering and boosting”) in Subpart W will report emissions for all the source categories listed in 40 CFR 98.232(j).  This includes stationary and portable fuel combustion equipment emissions that may have previously been reported under Subpart C.

question: How do I determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for my gathering pipelines?
answer: To determine the gas to oil ratio (GOR) for gathering pipelines, the GOR must be calculated for each well with vented or flared natural gas. If the GOR for individual wells is not available, the GOR from a cluster of wells in the sub-basin can be used. The GOR is calculated in standard cubic feet of gas per barrel of oil. The average GOR, in standard cubic feet of gas per barrel of oil, is reported for completions with hydraulic fracturing that have a GOR of 300 scf/STB or greater. Gathering pipelines operating on a vacuum and gathering pipelines with a GOR less than 300 scf/STB are not included in this industry segment. The GOR is used to calculate CH4, CO2, and N2O annual emissions as specified in the regulations.

truth: The gathering and boosting system owner or operator can use a direct measurement of GOR through either onsite measurement or by sending samples out for laboratory analysis. The timing and duration of the sampling/measurement program should follow existing regulatory requirements, which include standard methods published by a consensus-based standards organization or industry standard practices. See 40 CFR 98.234(b). The EPA realizes that owners or operators may calculate GOR for other reasons such as documenting fluid quality for financial transactions, equipment optimization or other state/federal reporting requirements. These values can be used where appropriate.A825. 40 CFR Part 98, Subpart W does not prescribe a specific approach to calculate GOR. Gathering and boosting system operators may use the best approach for their facility, including direct measurement, calculation from other measured data, and standard estimation measures. We note that within the EPA’s 2016 updates to New Source Performance Standards for the oil and natural gas sector, GOR is defined as the ratio of the volume of gas at standard temperature and pressure that is produced from a volume of oil when depressurized to a standard temperature and pressure. See 40 CFR 60.5430a.

question: My gathering pipeline is exempt based on Gas to Oil Ratio. Does the exemption only apply to the pipeline itself, or is all equipment along the pipeline excluded as well?
answer: The exemption based on Gas to Oil Ratio (GOR) applies to the entire gathering pipeline and all equipment along the pipeline. Therefore, if the gathering pipeline is exempt, all equipment along the pipeline is also excluded.

question: Can facilities covered by the Subpart W Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting industry segment use Subpart C emission factors for calculating combustion emissions?
answer: Facilities covered by the Subpart W Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting industry segment cannot use Subpart C emission factors for calculating combustion emissions. The appropriate factors for calculating emissions are specified in Table W-1A, Table W-1B, and Table W-1C of Subpart W, and the calculation method is defined in § 98.233(j) of the regulation.

truth: Combustion emissions for the Onshore Petroleum and Natural Gas Gathering and Boosting segment are calculated using methods outlined in 40 CFR 98.233(z). Those methods provide flexibility to use Subpart C emission factors if the fuel combusted is natural gas, is pipeline quality, and has a minimum high heat value of 950 Btu per standard cubic foot. If the fuel meets those criteria, then you may use the emission factor for natural gas as listed in 40 CFR Part 98, Subpart C, Table C-1.  See 40 CFR 98.233(z)(1).

question: Section 98.230(a)(3) states that processing plants "that do not fractionate but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater" are included in the source category. Is this based on annual average daily flow or max design capacity?
answer: Section 98.230(a)(3) states that processing plants 'that do not fractionate but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater' are included in the source category. This 'annual average throughput' refers to the average daily flow of natural gas over the course of a year, based on the actual flow rates of natural gas through the processing plant on a daily basis, averaged over the entire year. Therefore, it is based on annual average daily flow rather than max design capacity.

question: What is the definition of  "fractionate" and "fractionation" in 98.230(a)(3)?
answer: In 98.230(a)(3), the term 'fractionate' refers to the process of separating a mixture into its individual components or fractions, typically based on their differing boiling points. 'Fractionation' is the act of performing this separation, which is a key process in natural gas liquids fractionation where the mixed NGLs are separated into individual constituent products. This process is critical for the production of various valuable components such as ethane, propane, butanes, and natural gasoline.

question: Under onshore natural gas processing where are vent emissions reported?
answer: Vent emissions from onshore natural gas processing are reported for compressor venting at an onshore petroleum and natural gas production facility as specified in § 98.232(c)(19) or an onshore petroleum and natural gas gathering and boosting facility as specified in § 98.233(c)(11). This information can be found in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title 40, Part 98, which outlines the specific reporting requirements for vent emissions from onshore natural gas processing.

question: In 98.230(a)(3), is 25 mmscf per day the design capacity for a processing plant or the actual capacity?
answer: The design capacity of a processing plant as per 98.230(a)(3) is the maximum amount of gas that a processing plant is capable of processing under its design conditions. This is the theoretical maximum capacity of the plant and is not necessarily the actual amount of gas processed on a daily basis. Therefore, 25 mmscf per day is likely the design capacity for the processing plant, not the actual capacity.

question: If a natural gas processing plant is co-located with an underground storage facility and they share compression, can they report as one combined facility?
answer: Based on the specifications provided, if a natural gas processing plant is co-located with an underground storage facility and they share compression, they can report as one combined facility. This means that they can be considered and reported as a single integrated operation, potentially streamlining reporting and regulatory requirements.

question: If fuel gas lines are not owned or operated by a gas processing facility, but are on the gas processing facility property, do the fuel gas lines need to be monitored for equipment leaks?
answer: Based on the provided information, if the fuel gas lines are on the gas processing facility property, they do not need to be monitored for equipment leaks unless a flow meter is not installed at any point in the line supplying fuel gas or an upstream common pipe. In that case, monitoring for equipment leaks would be necessary.

truth: The definition of facility in 98.6 requires equipment to be under “common ownership or common control.”  Therefore, based on the information provided, the fuel gas lines are not subject to the rule because they are not owned and/or operated by the reporting gas processing facility’s owners/operators.
relevance_reason: The answer partially addresses the question by stating that monitoring for equipment leaks would be necessary if a flow meter is not installed at any point in the line supplying fuel gas or an upstream common pipe. groundedness_reason: The answer logically follows from the information provided in the context. It states that if a flow meter is not installed at any point in the line supplying fuel gas or an upstream common pipe, monitoring for equipment leaks would be necessary. Therefore, if the fuel gas lines are on the gas processing facility property, they do not need to be monitored for equipment leaks unless a flow meter is not installed.

answer: Yes, a facility that processes an inlet gas stream with a methane content of less than 70% by volume and a heating value of less than 910 Btu per standard cubic foot would be excluded from the Onshore Natural Gas Processing segment as per the provided environmental regulations and criteria.

truth: The definition of “natural gas” in the final rule revision (December 23, 2011) excludes the composition and heat value specification and simply states: “Natural gas means a naturally occurring mixture or process derivative of hydrocarbon and non-hydrocarbon gases found in geologic formations beneath the earth's surface, of which its constituents include, but are not limited to, methane, heavier hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide.  Natural gas may be field quality, pipeline quality, or process gas.”  Based upon the finalized definition of “natural gas”, a facility that processes an inlet gas stream which is field gas could be included in the Onshore Natural Gas Processing segment if the process otherwise meets the definition of Onshore Natural Gas Processing.

The provided environmental regulations and criteria state that a facility with an inlet gas stream containing less than 70% methane by volume and a heating value of less than 910 Btu per standard cubic foot is excluded from the Onshore Natural Gas Processing segment.
dontknowness_reason: The answer completely answers the question and conveys no uncertainty.
coherence_reason: The answer is well-structured and coherent, providing a clear and concise response to the question with accurate information and references to the provided environmental regulations and criteria.

question: Are facilities designed solely to fractionate natural gas liquid streams (and do not receive a gaseous form of natural gas containing methane) subject to subpart W?
answer: Yes, facilities designed solely to fractionate natural gas liquid streams are subject to subpart W. This includes natural gas liquids fractionators and onshore natural gas processing plants that solely fractionate a liquid stream, as well as any other facilities involved in the extraction, fractionation, and distribution of natural gas liquids.

question: How should I calculate the reporting threshold for onshore natural gas processing plants that do not fractionate gas liquids?
answer: For onshore natural gas processing plants that do not fractionate gas liquids but have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater, the gases to be reported are CO2, CH4, and N2O as specified in the rule. The reporting threshold for these plants can be calculated based on the annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater.

truth: The Rule states in §98.230(a) that the onshore natural gas processing industry includes all plants that fractionate, as well as all plants that do not fractionate that have an annual average throughput of 25 MMscf per day or greater.  Only those non-fractionating facilities with an annual average throughput of less than 25 MMscf per day would not be subject to reporting under subpart W even if the reporting threshold is triggered in Subpart C.  The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.

question: What is the basis for the 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) and how often must a facility re-evaluate whether it falls below this threshold?
answer: The 25 MMscfd threshold for gas processing facilities in 98.230(a)(3) is based on the emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) such as CO2, CH4, and N2O. This threshold is used to determine the applicability of subpart W reporting requirements for onshore natural gas processing facilities. Facilities must re-evaluate whether they fall below this threshold annually to determine if they are subject to the reporting requirements.

truth: However, please note that if, in year 2, your throughput capacity is less than 25 MMscf per day, you are not required to calculate and report GHG emissions from gas processing in year 2.  You would still be required to report other covered emissions at your facility.  This is because gas processing would not be an applicable segment for year 2.  Nevertheless, your facility would still be required to report in year 2, even if facility-wide emissions are less than 25,000mt CO2e, and would continue to report until you meet the criteria in 98.2(i) for ceasing to report.  The gas processing plant throughput threshold in 98.230(a)(3) is based on annual average throughput.  This throughput is re-evaluated annually.  Once you are subject to the rule (e.g., your facility contains a source category listed in Table A-4), your facility must continue complying with all the requirements of this part, even if the facility does not meet the applicability requirements in a future year (i.e., 25,000 mtCO2e for petroleum and natural gas systems). The definition of the source category for petroleum and natural gas systems, under onshore natural gas processing, refers to a processing facility that does not fractionate and has a throughput of 25MMscf per day or greater.  Because a gas processing facility that is over 25 MMscf per day meets the definition of the source category for subpart W, any facility that becomes subject to the rule in whole or in part because of a natural gas processing facility, would have to continue reporting until it meets the conditions for cessation of reporting in 98.2(i).

question: Which takes precedence for determining the Subpart W applicability of a natural gas processing facility- the 25,000 MT CO2e threshold (under 98.2(a)(2)) or the 25 MMscf per day throughput (under 98.230(a)(3))?
answer: Based on the analyses, the 25,000 MT CO2e threshold under 98.2(a)(2) takes precedence for determining the Subpart W applicability of a natural gas processing facility over the 25 MMscf per day throughput under 98.230(a)(3). This means that the facility's CO2e emissions would be the primary factor in determining its applicability under Subpart W.

truth: Since the throughput of the facility was identified in the question as 30 MMscf per day throughput capacity, this exceeds the exclusion identified in the §98.230(a)(3) for processing facilities that do not fractionate.  Therefore, this facility falls under the onshore natural gas processing industry segment definition as defined in §98.230(a)(3) and these emissions would be included in the applicability determination for your facility.  (If the throughput were less than 25 MMscf this source would not have been considered in the applicability determination for the facility.)  However, based on the information provided, since the processing facility has less than 25,000 metric tons CO2e in combined emissions from stationary combustion, flaring, vented, and fugitive sources, the facility does not need to report under subpart W.  Both the 25,000 metric ton CO2e threshold (from §98.2(a)(2)) and the 25 MMscf per day annual average throughput (from §98.230(a)(3)) are considered when determining subpart W applicability for a natural gas processing facility.

answer: Yes, engineering calculations may be used for flare gas composition in equations W-19 through W-21 if the flared stream is a combination of gases from before and after the demethanizer as well as hydrocarbon product. It is important to consider the specific composition of the gases and the demethanizer process to accurately apply the equations for flare gas composition.

truth: EPA agrees that in the event that it is not possible to distinguish the source streams from the processing facility being flared, whether being located upstream or downstream of the demethanizer, or being a hydrocarbon product stream, reporters may use engineering calculations based on process knowledge and best available data.
relevance_reason: The answer accurately and completely addresses the question by confirming that engineering calculations may be used for flare gas composition in equations W-19 through W-21 if the flared stream is a combination of gases from before and after the demethanizer as well as hydrocarbon product. The answer also provides additional context and guidance for accurately applying the equations.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate response to the question asked, citing the specific equations (W-19 through W-21) and noting the importance of considering the composition of the gases and the demethanizer process. The answer logically follows from the information contained in the context.

However, there is some room for improvement in terms of sentence structure and flow.

question: Does the onshore natural gas processing source category include the dehydrator or "knockout pot" in the example?
answer: Yes, the onshore natural gas processing source category includes the dehydrator or 'knockout pot' as it is used to dehydrate the petroleum and/or natural gas to a natural gas processing facility, as specified in the regulations.

question: Under subpart W, are we required to calculate potential GHG emissions from compressors at a natural gas processing facility that are only used for refrigeration and use 100% propane?
answer: Based on the information provided in subpart W of the EPA's Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program, the calculation of potential GHG emissions from compressors at a natural gas processing facility that are only used for refrigeration and use 100% propane is not required. The emissions from compressors used solely for refrigeration and utilizing 100% propane are not subject to reporting requirements for GHG emissions under subpart W. Therefore, there is no need to calculate potential GHG emissions from these specific compressors under subpart W.

truth: 98.232 (d) states that “for onshore natural gas processing, report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from the following sources”.  For example, if the compressor stream is 100% propane then the emissions will not include CO2, CH4 and N2O emissions and therefore will not have to be reported under subpart W.  However, if the facility exceeds the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold then the owner or operator must report combustion emissions for this compressor under subpart C.
relevance_reason: The answer accurately addresses the question and provides relevant information based on the context. It also explains that there is no need to calculate potential GHG emissions from compressors used solely for refrigeration and utilizing 100% propane under subpart W.
groundedness_reason: The answer provides a clear and accurate response to the question, citing the information provided in subpart W of the EPA's Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program. question: Under Subpart W of Part 98, the definition of Natural Gas Processing provides an unclear explanation of fractionation, additionally, fractionation is not defined within the rule.
answer: Fractionation is not explicitly defined within Subpart W of Part 98. However, the facility in question is subject to the provisions of part 78 and is required to comply with the applicable subparts of part 98, specifically subpart C (Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources). The facility must report GHG emissions under subpart C if it contains one or more stationary fuel combustion sources and meets the applicability requirements. Additionally, the facility must follow the requirements of subpart C, including the Tier 4 Calculation Methodology and all associated requirements for Tier 4. The facility should also retain records of all parameters monitored for each stationary fuel combustion unit. Therefore, the facility is subject to reporting GHG emissions under subpart C of part 98, but the definition of fractionation within Subpart W remains unclear.

question: What is the difference between the methods in 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1) for monitoring tank emissions?  How do we treat intermittent emission from the storage tank? Can we use an alternative method to quantify the emissions?
answer: The difference between the methods in 98.233(k) and 98.234(a)(1) for monitoring tank emissions lies in the approach. In 98.233(k), monitoring tank emissions involves estimating emissions by monitoring the changes in container weights and inventories using Equation T–1 of this subpart, while in 98.234(a)(1), the monitoring of tank emissions involves directly measuring the tank vent using a flow meter or high volume sampler according to methods in § 98.234(b) or (d) for a duration of 5 minutes. Intermittent emissions from the storage tank can be treated by conducting monitoring at least annually and sampling at least one-third of the equipment annually. An alternative method to quantify the emissions can be used only if it meets the site-specific leak monitoring method requirements in § 98.124(f)(1) and is documented and reported accordingly.

truth: The purpose of this detection and measurement is to determine and quantify any continuous gas emissions from condensate storage tanks.  The most common source of vapor emissions from a transmission compressor station condensate tank would be liquid transfer from compressor scrubber dump valves.  These sources operating properly would be intermittent transfer of liquids from high pressure vessels to an atmospheric storage tank, with a short term flashing of dissolved gas, which is assumed to be less than 5 minutes in duration.  Malfunction of scrubber dump valves can result in high pressure vapor leaking through the valve, into the condensate tank, and out the tank roof vent, which would vent indefinitely.  This continuous release of vapor is detected as a continuous blow of gas from the condensate tank roof vent using a leak imaging camera or by using an acoustic through-valve leak detection instrument.  Based on the current rule, when using an optical gas imaging instrument, the tank needs to be monitored to determine whether the tank vapors are continuous for 5 minutes; see section 98.233(k)(2).  So if a leak is detected per requirements of 98.234(a)(1) and is continuous per the requirements of 98.233(k)(2) then the reporter has to measure the emissions per requirements in 98.233(k)(2)(i)-(iv).  The reporter has the choice of using an acoustic leak detection device to detect and measure leaks per requirements in 98.234(a)(5).  You cannot use alternative methods to those outlined in the rule.

It also mentions the requirement for using an alternative method and the conditions that must be met for it to be used.

question: In the natural gas transmission segment, do only condensate tanks at the facilities require leak checks (not other tanks at the facility or not at the facility)?
answer: Yes, only condensate tanks at the facilities require leak checks. Other tanks at the facility do not require leak checks.

question: The definition of the onshore natural gas transmission compression includes "any stationary combustion of compressors that move natural gas at elevated pressure
answer: The definition of the onshore natural gas transmission compression includes 'any stationary combination of compressors that move natural gas at elevated pressure.' Therefore, the facilities must use the appropriate default total hydrocarbon leaker emission factors for compressor components in gas service and non-compressor components during the compression process.

question: How does a natural gas compressor station that operates compressors for natural gas transmission and an emergency generator determine subpart applicability?
answer: The natural gas compressor station must report CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from various sources including reciprocating compressor venting, centrifugal compressor venting, transmission storage tanks, blowdown vent stacks, natural gas pneumatic device venting, and flare stack emissions. The facility must also indicate compliance with specific regulations and whether any equipment components are subject to fugitive emissions standards. The emissions must be calculated based on cumulative hours of venting, days, or times of operation as per the regulations. Therefore, the facility is required to report these emissions based on the specified sources and operational parameters.

truth: For the purpose of determining the applicability of 40 CFR part 98 for the 2010 reporting year, the facility should calculate the emissions from the gas compressors pursuant to 40 CFR 98.30(a)(2). So long as a the emergency generators meet the definition of “emergency equipment” as stated in 98.6, emissions from the emergency generators are exempt and should not be calculated.  If the facility is subject to 40 CFR part 98, you should report combustion emissions pursuant to the applicable requirements of subpart C (General Stationary Fuel Combustion Sources).  Pursuant to 40 CFR 98.2, if a facility’s calculated total annual emissions are less than 25,000 metric tons of CO2e and the facility does not contain a source category listed in Table A-3 of 40 CFR part 98, subpart A, then the facility does not have to report under 40 CFR part 98 as a direct emitter.

question: Are CO2 pipelines subject to the Onshore natural gas transmission compression segment under 40 CFR 98 subpart W?
answer: Yes, CO2 pipelines are subject to the Onshore natural gas transmission compression segment under 40 CFR 98 subpart W.

question: Are unintentional natural gas releases such as those resulting from accidental releases subject to reporting?
answer: Yes, unintentional natural gas releases such as those resulting from accidental releases are subject to reporting. The regulations require reporting of various emissions including CO2, CH4, and N2O from a wide range of sources such as pneumatic device venting, well venting, blowdown vent stacks, compressor venting, and equipment leaks.

truth: Onshore natural gas transmission pipeline facilities must report emissions of carbon dioxide and methane from blowdown vent stacks to the GHGRP if facility-wide annual emissions are 25,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalents (mtCO2e) or greater. This requirement applies to blowdown vent stack emissions from the depressurization of equipment for both planned and emergency shutdowns.

question: How do we report emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir?
answer: Emissions from separate facilities that inject or withdraw gas from the same underground storage reservoir must be reported individually by each facility. Each facility is responsible for reporting the emissions it generates. The emissions from the shared underground storage reservoir should be reported by each respective facility based on its own activities and operations. This means that each facility should accurately report its own emissions without combining them with emissions from other facilities sharing the same reservoir.

truth: Underground storage and compression and transmission compression are two separate industry segments.  A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions from all applicable industry segments against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  For a response to the question related to multipurpose facilities and dual purpose equipment, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (see pp. 1606-1608 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf).  If multiple owners or operators use the same underground storage operation, one designated representative must be appointed for reporting purposes.

question: Could EPA clarify that the natural gas stored in high pressure steel bottles at peak-shaving stations should NOT be considered an underground natural gas storage facility under Subpart W?
answer: Based on the text analysis, the natural gas stored in high pressure steel bottles at peak-shaving stations should NOT be considered an underground natural gas storage facility under Subpart W. Since there were no relevant findings from table or formula analysis, the conclusion is solely based on the text analysis result.

truth: High pressure steel bottles that store natural gas at peak-shaving stations without any subsurface storage per section 98.230(a)(5) would not be considered underground natural gas storage under Subpart W.  However, if the high pressure steel bottles are located at underground storage per section 98.230(a)(5) then the equipment leak sources listed in 98.232(f)(5) would be subject to reporting.

truth: A “facility”, as defined in 40 CFR 98.6, must determine if it contains any of the industry segments listed in subpart W and compare its emissions against the 25,000 mtCO2e threshold defined in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2) to determine applicability.  Underground natural gas storage is as defined in §98.230(a)(5) and includes reporting of GHGs as listed in §98.232(f)(1) through (5).  Therefore, the reporter needs to determine all applicable sources as per this industry segment definition and sources to report.  Specifically, filters and separators are not listed as sources under 98.232(f)(1) through (5) but if filters or separators are associated with any sources under this section, reporting of those listed sources is still required.  The sources required to report under the underground storage source category are listedin §98.232(f).  In this list dehydration units are not included therefore reporting from this source type is not required.

question: If a company owns and operates an underground storage facility but the associated storage wellheads are owned jointly with a second company but operated by the second company, should the respective operators to submit separate emission reports?
answer: If a company owns and operates an underground storage facility but the associated storage wellheads are owned jointly with a second company but operated by the second company, the respective operators should submit separate emission reports. This is because each operator is responsible for the emissions associated with the specific equipment they operate, and separate reporting ensures accountability for the emissions from each operator's activities.

question: Why do natural gas storage facilities not have different emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment.
answer: The natural gas storage facilities do not have different emission factors for compressor and non-compressor components like those for the natural gas transmission segment. The emission factors are based on the type of equipment and the activities conducted at the facility, rather than specifically differentiating between compressor and non-compressor components.

question: Does Subpart W require reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility or does reporting start only when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage?
answer: The reporting of emissions during the salt dome mining process to create an underground natural gas storage facility is not explicitly addressed in the provided information. However, based on the details provided, the reporting requirements under subpart W of this part apply to facilities required to report under onshore petroleum and natural gas production. The emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from stationary combustion units are to be reported under subpart C of this part, along with other applicable subparts. Therefore, reporting would likely start when natural gas is introduced for load balancing or storage, as that is when the emissions from stationary combustion units would need to be reported under subpart C.

truth: Under 98.230(a)(5) reporting is only required for “…salt dome caverns that store natural gas…” Methane emissions from building of a storage facility are not included in the reporting for subpart W.  Emissions reporting is required when the storage facility is operational.

question: How should we report a facility that combines onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage by injecting natural gas for the purposes of both enhanced oil recoveray and storage?
answer: The facility that combines onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage by injecting natural gas for the purposes of both enhanced oil recovery and storage should report all relevant activities and emissions associated with both the production and storage processes. This includes reporting the injection and recovery of natural gas into and from the underground reservoirs, emissions from atmospheric pressure fixed roof storage tanks, and the flow of gas to storage tanks. The facility should also ensure compliance with the appropriate regulations for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage, as outlined in the relevant sections of the regulations.

truth: What constitutes a facility, how to determine the reporting threshold, and reporting of emissions from collocated and dual purpose equipment is as follows: 1) As a first step the reporter must determine the emissions from all equipment listed in 98.232(c) for onshore petroleum and production.  Per section 98.231(a) only sources listed in 98.232(c) need to be considered for threshold determination for onshore petroleum and natural gas production. 98.238 defines “facility” for the purposes of onshore petroleum and natural gas systems.  Per the requirements of 98.3 each “facility” must submit a GHG report for all source categories at that “facility”.  2) Note that while identifying onshore production emissions sources reporters have to determine whether the source is “on the well pad or associated with a well pad”.  The location of production wells within other facilities is inconsequential to this determination.  Sources on a well pad or associated with a well pad across the entire reporting basin have to be taken into consideration.  If your emissions from onshore petroleum and natural gas production are equal to or greater than 25,000mtCO2e, then onshore petroleum and natural gas production facilities report as a separate facility and include all emissions sources listed in 98.232(c).  3) Except for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution, which have unique facility definitions, all other segments subject to subpart W are considered in the threshold determination for a single facility.  You would also include emissions from other source categories at your facility (e.g., stationary combustion).  If there are emissions sources that are dual purpose then the rule requires this piece of equipment to be reported under the majority use industry segment based on guidance provided in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14 (pp. 1606-1608).  4) For collocated industry segments, which cannot occur in the case of onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas distribution due to the requirements in 98.231(a), EPA has provided guidance on emissions reporting in EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1024-14.  Based on the information provided, the facility cannot be reported as onshore production and natural gas processing combined (see point 1 above).  For all the other segments, the report should use guidance in points 2-3 above to determine the segment under which the facility should be categorized.
relevance_reason: The answer addresses the main aspects of the question by stating that the facility should report all relevant activities and emissions associated with both the production and storage processes, including the injection and recovery of natural gas, emissions from atmospheric pressure fixed roof storage tanks, and the flow of gas to storage tanks. However, the answer does not explicitly mention the need to comply with the appropriate regulations for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage, which is why it is not a perfect answer.

The answer also mentions the need to comply with the appropriate regulations for onshore petroleum and natural gas production and natural gas storage, as outlined in the relevant sections of the regulations. question: Are dehydration units that are used to dehydrate natural gas extracted from underground storage included within the definition of underground natural gas storage facility?
answer: The dehydrator units are not explicitly included within the definition of underground natural gas storage facilities. However, they are integral to the movement and processing of natural gas, and their emissions must be reported, including the vent emissions from the dehydrator unit. Therefore, while not explicitly classified as underground natural gas storage facilities, they are an important component of the overall natural gas processing and storage infrastructure.

question: For liquefied natural gas facility equipment that is in gas service, is only the equipment listed in Table W-5 (Vapor Recovery Compressor) required to be reported if it is found to be leaking as defined in the rule?
answer: Yes, for liquefied natural gas facility equipment that is in gas service, only the equipment listed in Table W-5 (Vapor Recovery Compressor) is required to be reported if it is found to be leaking as defined in the rule. The emission factors provided in Table W-5A are specific to LNG storage components and should be used for reporting leaks from this equipment.

truth: LNG facilities will not be surveying the valves, connectors, and other components that are in Gas Service under 98.233(q).  At an LNG facility, a compressor that recovers vapor, but is designed so that it does not have reportable emissions of methane-containing gas, such as a flooded screw compressor, or one with seals purged with pressurized nitrogen, will not be reported, in accordance with the rule and the EPA’s response in Response to Public Comments, EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1026-7 (see pp. 45-46 in http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part1.pdf).  Vapor recovery compressors use a population emission factor, hence there is no leak detection required.  Reporters have to count the number of vapor recovery compressors and use the population emission factor.

question: Do I have to calculate emissions from operational LNG storage tank venting at LNG storage facilities or LNG import or export terminals?
answer: Yes, you must calculate emissions from operational LNG storage tank venting at LNG storage facilities or LNG import or export terminals. This includes reporting various emissions such as CH4, CO2, and N2O from different sources including blowdown vent stacks, pneumatic device venting, storage tanks, and flare stack emissions as per the regulations specified in the provided content. The calculation will involve considering the volume and duration of venting, as well as the specific emissions factors for LNG storage tank venting provided by the EPA. It's important to ensure compliance with the applicable regulations and accurately calculate the emissions from operational LNG storage tank venting.

truth: To answer the second question about pressure relief valves, Sections 98.233(q)(6) and (7) state that emission factors for “…equipment leaks detected from valves, pump seals, connectors, and other” shall be used from Tables W-5 and W-6 in the rule. A pressure relief valve is a special type of valve and falls in the category of "other," so this emission source is included in the leak detection survey and required to be reported.  Regarding your first question: sections 98.232(g) and 98.232(h) do no include venting from LNG storage tanks as an emission source; therefore venting emissions from LNG storage tank are not required for LNG storage or for LNG import and export equipment.  However, if the LNG storge tank is blown down to atmosphere, then section 98.232(h) does require reporting.

question: How are we to treat GHG reporting applicability offshore LNG where the offshore terminal is basically buoy out in the ocean where a ship connects, regasifies the LNG onboard and injects natural gas under pressure into the pipeline?
answer: Offshore LNG import and export terminals that regasify LNG and inject natural gas into the pipeline are not explicitly mentioned in the provided information. However, based on the specified guidelines, the equipment and processes involved in LNG import and export facilities would be subject to reporting requirements for CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions, as well as the GHG mole fraction in natural gas stored in the LNG import and export industry segment. The specific emissions from the regasification process and injection into the pipeline may need to be calculated based on the available data and applicable methods. Therefore, the reporting applicability for offshore LNG terminals would depend on the emission sources and the specific equipment involved in the regasification and injection processes.

truth: The LNG import and export terminal source category includes offshore equipment that receives imported LNG via ocean transport, stores LNG, re-gasifies LNG, and delivers re-gasified natural gas to a natural gas transmission or distribution system.  The floating vessels described above, not the ships, are considered LNG import terminal facilities.  Applicability would be determined by determining the estimated emissions and comparing against the threshold in 40 CFR 98.2(a)(2).

question: Is an LNG Storage vessel considered "above ground" if any portion of the vessel is above grade?
answer: Yes, an LNG storage vessel is considered 'above ground' if any portion of the vessel is located above grade. This is in accordance with the definition of LNG storage, which specifies that it includes onshore LNG storage vessels located above ground.

question: At LNG Storage sites, how should pumps that are internal and submerged be treated?
answer: Pumps that are internal and submerged at LNG storage sites should be equipped with dual mechanical seals to prevent hydrocarbon gas emissions and ensure compliance with environmental regulations.

question: Are LNG storage sites located adjacent to subpart D facilities under "common control" required to report emissions under the subpart D "facility" or should the LDC report the emissions under subpart W?
answer: Yes, LNG storage sites located adjacent to subpart D facilities under 'common control' are required to report emissions under the subpart D 'facility'. The LDC should report the emissions under subpart W.

truth: Based on the information provided, the questioner would report as a single facility under 40 CFR 98.  The single facility would be required to report emissions separately for subparts C, D and W in the EPA electronic greenhouse gas reporting system (eGGRT).  In regard to specific sources, subpart W requires the reporting of process and emissions from any source listed in 98.232(g) sent to a flare from LNG storage facilities, as defined in 40 CFR 98.230, under subpart W according to the calculation procedures outlined in 98.233.  Additional applicable emissions are to be reported under subpart D according to the methods described in subpart D.  Finally, stationary combustion emissions are to be reported under subpart C.

question: For a liquefied natural gas import facility, do boil-off venting emissions from an LNG storage tank need to be reported?
answer: Yes, boil-off venting emissions from an LNG storage tank need to be reported. The emissions from blowdown vent stacks must be accounted for, including natural gas and/or CO2 released due to maintenance and/or blowdown operations. Additionally, emissions from reciprocating compressor venting, centrifugal compressor venting, flare stack emissions, equipment leaks, dehydrator vents, transmission storage tanks, natural gas pneumatic device venting, and flare stack emissions must also be reported.

truth: Section 98.232(h) does not include boil-off venting from LNG storage tanks as an emission source under LNG import and export equipment; therefore, boil-off venting emissions from LNG storage tanks are not required.  However, if the LNG storage tank is blown down to the atmosphere then reporting is required under 98.233(i).

question: Are natural gas distribution facilities required to report emissions from residential and commercial customer meters and associated regulator(s) under §98.232(i )?
answer: Yes, natural gas distribution facilities are required to report emissions from residential and commercial customer meters and associated regulator(s) under §98.232(i). This requirement applies to both residential and commercial customer meters and their associated regulators.

question: Please explain how many leak detection surveys must be conducted a calendar year?  Must a facility indicate in advance how many surveys will be conducted in the year?
answer: At least one complete leak detection survey must be conducted during a calendar year. If multiple complete leak detection surveys are conducted in a calendar year, the results from each complete survey must be used. The choice of leak detection method and the number of surveys conducted must be in accordance with the regulations specified in 40 CFR part 60, appendix A–7 to part 60 of this chapter and 40 CFR part 98, subpart A. A facility does not need to indicate in advance how many surveys will be conducted in the year, but the surveys must comply with the regulations.

truth: For natural gas distribution, a facility, which is the collection of all distribution pipelines, metering stations, and regulating stations that are operated by an LDC, is required to do at least one facility wide leak detection survey per calendar year and has the option to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys; if the facility selects this option, the additional facility-wide survey(s) must be completed during the same calendar year in order to account for fixing one or more leaks in the annual GHG report.  If the facility chooses to fix one or more leaks and conduct another survey to determine that the component is not leaking, it must conduct a facility wide leak detection survey in order to account for fixing the leak(s) in the annual GHG report.  As leaks are random in nature and while some leaks are fixed others are likely to occur.  Therefore, a comprehensive survey is the only statistically relevant manner by which to establish facility-wide leak emissions rates and account for leaks repaired.  Please see the response to comment EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1014-9 (Response to Comments, pp. 1281-1282, http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf) for further details.  It is very important to note that the requirement to conduct additional facility-wide leak detection surveys should a company wish to account for fixing a leak does not preclude in any way a company from repairing a leak.  If a company chooses to conduct only one facility-wide leak detection survey in a calendar year but finds a leak during the survey, the company can and is encouraged to fix the leak.  The leak detected though, as noted above, must be reported as a leaker for the entire calendar year should the company choose not to conduct a second survey.

question: What happens if an LDC goes out to a custody transfer city gate station year after year and finds that it has no leaking components?  Could EPA provide a sunset provision so that annual leak surveys would no longer be required?
answer: Based on the regulations, if an LDC goes out to a custody transfer city gate station year after year and finds that it has no leaking components, there is no provision for a sunset clause to discontinue the annual leak surveys. The requirement for conducting annual leak detection surveys is not contingent on the absence of leaking components in previous years. Therefore, the LDC would still be required to conduct annual leak detection surveys as mandated by the regulations.

truth: Equipment/component leaks are random in nature and minimal leaks in one year do not guarantee similar leak levels in the future.  There are no sunsetting provisions for individual emissions sources, only facilities.  EPA has provided provisions that allow facilities to stop reporting under certain conditions and with prior notification to EPA.  Please see 40 CFR 98.2(i) (1) – (i) (3).  EPA addressed sunset provisions in general in the proposal to the 2009 Mandatory Reporting of Greenhouse Gases Rule (74 FR 16478).

answer: No, the monitoring plan that results in 10% of stations being monitored in each of years 1 and 2, 40% in year 3, 20% in year 4 and 20% in year five would not be consistent with the rule language of 'approximately equal across all years in the cycle.' This conclusion is based on the text analysis, which indicates that the monitoring percentages are not approximately equal across all years in the cycle. Therefore, the monitoring plan does not meet the requirement of being consistent with the rule language.

truth: As noted in the preamble, the purpose of this provision was to reduce burden for reporters, including the option to better align survey frequencies between the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program and Department of Transportation regulations.  The statement in the preamble regarding a “minimum of 20 percent of their total number of stations being leak surveyed annually” was considered for cases where a facility chose a period of less than 5 years. We also recognize that there is a related comment and response in, “Mandatory Greenhouse Gas Reporting Rule: EPA's Response to Public Comments: “2011 Technical Revisions to the Petroleum and Natural Gas Systems Category of the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Rule” (see DCN: EPA-HQ-OAR-2011-0512-0030) where EPA may also appear to reject the 10%-10%-40%-20%-20% approach outlined above.  However, EPA understood the commenter’s recommendation as to be suggesting measurement of 10% of stations per year, over a ten year period. EPA’s objection to the comment to monitor 10% of stations per year would have been inconsistent with a five-year cycle.  Yes.   According to 98.233(q)(8)(i), “Natural gas distribution facilities may choose to conduct leak detection at T-D transfer stations over multiple years, not exceeding a five year period to cover all T-D transfer stations.  If the facility chooses to use the multiple year option, then the number of T-D transfer stations monitored in each year should be approximately equal across all years in the cycle without monitoring the same station twice during the multiple year survey.”  EPA confirms that an approach of conducting monitoring at 10% of the facilities in each of the first two years, followed by 40%, 20% and 20% in years three, four and five would be consistent with the rule language that the number of stations monitored be “approximately equal” over the number of years surveyed.

question: What types of instruments are permissible for use in detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W?
answer: The permissible instruments for detecting equipment leaks and through valve leakage in Subpart W include the following: acoustic leak detection device, infrared laser beam illuminated instrument, equipment leak detection methods in appendix A–7 to part 60 of this chapter, Method 21, imaging instrument, flow meter, optical gas imaging instrument, and temporary meter such as a vane anemometer. Additionally, it's important to refer to the equipment leak detection methods in appendix A–7 to part 60 of this chapter for further guidance on permissible instruments.

truth: For conducting leak detection required by subpart W, reporters have the option to use optical gas imaging instruments, infrared laser beam illuminated instruments, or acoustic leak detection devices as outlined in 40 CFR 98.234(a).  In addition, reporters may use other instruments, however those instruments must comply with the provisions as stated in 40 CFR 98.234(a)(2).

question: Can data from a state permit-required fugitive emissions monitoring program already in place, which has a lower leak detection rate of 500 ppm, be used to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions under §98.233(q)?
answer: Yes, data from a state permit-required fugitive emissions monitoring program already in place, which has a lower leak detection rate of 500 ppm, can be used to estimate fugitive greenhouse gas emissions under §98.233(q). This conclusion is supported by the text analysis result.

question: Does 98.233(q), "Leak detection and leaker emission factors," apply to wellheads, separators at well site, storage tanks and other equipment defined by "production equipment"?
answer: Yes, 98.233(q), 'Leak detection and leaker emission factors,' do apply to wellheads, separators at well sites, storage tanks, and other equipment defined by 'production equipment'. This is based on the requirement to report each type of method used to conduct leak surveys, the indication of facility containing component types subject to or complying with § 98.233(q), and the calculation of equipment leak emissions using the procedures specified in paragraph (q)(2) of this section.

truth: Onshore production reporters do not need to perform leak detection under §98.233(q) for equipment leaks.  For an onshore petroleum and natural gas production facility, equipment leaks are calculated with the methodology in §98.233(r), using population count and population emissions factors.

question: In 98.236(c)(3)( i ) is the "total throughput off the acid gas removal unit" to be reported is the volume of gas exiting the AGR unit (outlet gas), not the volume of gas vented to atmosphere?
answer: Based on the text analysis, the total throughput off the acid gas removal unit to be reported is the volume of gas exiting the AGR unit (outlet gas), not the volume of gas vented to atmosphere. However, without additional information from table or formula analysis, it is important to verify this interpretation with the specific regulations or guidelines governing the reporting of total throughput for the AGR unit.

question: Do acid gas removal units which are used only to sweeten a liquid stream meet the definition of acid gas removal units?
answer: Yes, acid gas removal units used only to sweeten a liquid stream meet the definition of acid gas removal units. The definition of acid gas removal unit encompasses the separation of hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from sour natural gas using liquid or solid absorbents or membrane separators. It does not specify that the gas must be in a gaseous state for the unit to be considered an acid gas removal unit.

truth: The definition of acid gas removal unit in §98.238 states, “process unit that separates hydrogen sulfide and/or carbon dioxide from sour natural gas using liquid or solid absorbents or membrane separators.”  Acid gas removal units processing a liquid stream do not meet this definition, and reporters do not need to report emissions from these units.

question: If all of the emissions from an AGR unit are recovered and transferred outside of the facility, does the facility still need to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then "reduce" the emission to zero?
answer: Yes, if all the emissions from an AGR unit are recovered and transferred outside the facility, the facility still needs to calculate emissions pursuant to Section 98.233(d)(11) and then 'reduce' the emission to zero. This is because the adjustment of CO2 emissions estimated in paragraphs (d)(1) through (d)(10) of this section is required to account for the magnitude of C emissions from the acid gas removal unit, even if the emissions are recovered and transferred outside the facility. Therefore, the facility must still follow the specified calculation methods and adjust the emissions accordingly.

truth: With regards to acid gas injection wells and subparts PP and UU, please see the response to EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response to Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.  EPA requires reporters to calculate emissions from AGR units and then adjust them downwards by the amount transferred outside of the facility.  Therefore, if 100% of the CO2 recovered from an AGR unit is transferred outside of the facility, then CO2 emissions from the AGR unit must be calculated prior to determining the amount being transferred outside the facility.  Note that §98.236(c)(3) requires separate reporting of both the AGR emissions and emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility, even if the values are the same.

The answer is logically true based on the information contained in the context.

question: Can facilities performing on-site acid gas injection estimate their emissions downward according to the provisions in 98.233(d)(11) for AGR unit emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility?
answer: Yes, facilities performing on-site acid gas injection can estimate their emissions downward according to the provisions in 98.233(d)(11) for AGR unit emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility.

truth: Reporters performing on-site injection of acid gas may not adjust emissions downward. §98.233(d)(11) clearly states that you may only adjust emissions estimates downwards for emissions recovered and transferred OUTSIDE the facility.  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-0582-31 in the Response To Comments (pages 1474 - 1476) http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf.
relevance_reason: The answer directly addresses the question and provides a clear and accurate response, confirming that facilities performing on-site acid gas injection can estimate their emissions downward according to the provisions in 98.233(d)(11) for AGR unit emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility.
groundedness_reason: The answer directly states that facilities performing on-site acid gas injection can estimate their emissions downward according to the provisions in 98.233(d)(11) for AGR unit emissions recovered and transferred outside the facility, which logically follows from the information provided in the context.
dontknowness_reason: The answer completely answers the question and conveys no uncertainty.
coherence_reason: The answer is mostly coherent and provides a clear and direct response to the question.

question: For AGR vents is the use of a meter to measure flow rates required?
answer: Yes, the use of a meter to measure flow rates is required for AGR vents. The text analysis indicates that the calculation methods specified in the rule require the determination of average process vent flow rate, use of a flow meter or high volume sampler, and determination of volumetric flow at standard conditions using a temporary meter. This emphasizes the necessity of using a meter to measure flow rates for AGR vents in order to calculate emissions for CO2.

truth: The rule requires the use of a meter if one is in place.  If a continuous flow meter is not already in place, then reporters have the choice of installing a continuous flow meter or alternatively using an engineering calculation to estimate the flow rate; please see §98.233(d)(5).

question: For which units of measure are we required to calculate and report emissions using Equation W-3? May we use a flow meter to calculate annual emission CO2?
answer: Equation W-3 is used to calculate annual CO2 emissions for which units of measure are required. The methodology allows for the use of quality-assured data from continuous emission monitoring systems (CEMS) to calculate the annual CO2 mass emissions from all fuels combusted in a unit. Additionally, the Tier 3 Calculation Methodology specifies the use of Equations C3, C4, or C5 to calculate the annual CO2 mass emissions for each fuel, and the results from Equations X–1 through X–3 are used in Equation X–4 to calculate annual CO2 emissions. However, the provided information does not directly address the specific units of measure required for Equation W-3. As for using a flow meter to calculate annual CO2 emissions, it is mentioned that the methodology allows for the use of quality-assured data from continuous emission monitoring systems (CEMS), but it does not explicitly mention the use of a flow meter. To provide a more accurate response, further clarification on the specific units of measure for Equation W-3 and the relevance of using a flow meter for annual CO2 emission calculations is needed.

truth: The units of measure for emissions calculated in Equation W-3 are in cubic feet per year. However, §98.233(d)(10) requires that the volumetric emissions of equation W-3 be converted into mass emissions using §98.233(v)’s methods.  You must report emissions in metric tons of CO2e to meet the reporting requirements in §98.236(c)(3)(v).  If reporters use the methodology set forth in §98.233(d)(2), then a vent flow meter must be used to determine the total annual volume of vent gas flowing out of the AGR unit.

question: For blowdown vent stacks does the 98.233.i reference to containers less than 50 cubic feet total physical volume refer to a gas volume or a physical container volume?
answer: The reference to containers less than 50 cubic feet total physical volume refers to the physical container volume. This means that the volume of the container itself should be less than 50 cubic feet, not the gas volume contained within the container.

truth: The unique physical volume between isolation valves should be considered against the 50 cubic feet threshold for blowdown vent stacks.  As stated in 40 CRF § 98.233(i)(2), unique physical volumes smaller than 50 cubic feet are exempt from reporting under § 98.233(i).  Please see EPA-HQ-OAR-2009-0923-1018-27 in Response to Comments (pages 1464-1465) (http://www.epa.gov/ghgreporting/documents/pdf/2010/Subpart-W_RTC_part2.pdf).

question: May average blowdown volumes be used for industry segments (processing, transmission, and LNG imports-exports) where reporting of this emission source is required?
answer: Based on the provided information, the average blowdown volumes may be used for industry segments (processing, transmission, and LNG imports-exports) where reporting of this emission source is required. The methods specified in the regulations allow for the determination of volumetric flow at standard conditions from the blowdown vent using various techniques such as temporary meters, calibrated bagging, high volume sampler, and flow meters. Additionally, the retention of logs of the number of blowdowns per calendar year and the calculation of emissions for unique physical volumes further support the use of average blowdown volumes for reporting purposes. Therefore, it is acceptable to use average blowdown volumes for industry segments where reporting of blowdown vent stack emissions is required.

question: Will EPA approve the use of BAMM relating to the measurement of isolation valves at compressors in the shut down depressurized mode that are to be measured at least once every three calendar years?
answer: Based on the information provided, the EPA requires specific equipment such as continuous flow meters, composition analyzers, thermocouples, and pressure gauges to be calibrated at a frequency necessary to support the type of analysis specified in the GHG Monitoring Plan. For compressors measured in operating mode, volumetric emissions from blowdown valve leakage through the blowdown vent must be measured. The frequency and methods for performing measurements, sampling, and analysis are outlined in detail for various scenarios, including the calibration and measurement requirements. Therefore, the EPA's approval of the use of BAMM for the measurement of isolation valves at compressors in the shut down depressurized mode, to be measured at least once every three calendar years, would depend on whether BAMM meets the specific calibration and measurement requirements outlined by the EPA.

question: Will EPA approve the use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) relating to the measurement of individual compressor vents routed a common manifold?
answer: Based on the information gathered from text analysis, the EPA will approve the use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) for measuring individual compressor vents routed to a common manifold. The method involves measuring at a single point in the manifold downstream of all compressor inputs and, if practical, prior to comingling with other non-compressor emission sources. This measurement can be used to calculate combined volumetric emissions from the manifolded group of compressor sources. Additionally, specific methods for performing as found measurements from manifolded groups of reciprocating compressor sources are detailed in the regulations. These methods are essential for calculating volumetric GHG emissions from continuous monitoring of manifolded groups of reciprocating compressor sources. Therefore, it can be inferred that the EPA will approve the use of Subpart W BAMM for the measurement of individual compressor vents routed to a common manifold.

truth: Facilities approved to use BAMM are still required to use the calculation methodologies and equations in § 98.233, and must comply with the reporting requirements in § 98.236.  The totality of the circumstances related to conducting measurement on compressors vents routed to a common manifold, if fully explained in a proper Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) request, may be considered by EPA to constitute unique or unusual circumstances justifying the use of BAMM. Pursuant to a May 2013 final rule, Subpart W BAMM requests are due by June 30 of the year prior to the year in which reports are due (the “reporting year”) and for which BAMM is sought. As June 30, 2013 falls on a weekend, BAMM requests for the 2014 reporting year are due by July 1, 2013.

question: Will EPA approve the use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) relating to the measurement of compressor vents routed to flare?
answer: Based on the provided information, the use of Subpart W Best Available Monitoring Methods (BAMM) for well-related measurement data is permitted, except as provided in paragraph (l)(2) of this section. Best Available Monitoring Methods may include monitoring methods currently used by the facility that do not meet the specifications of this subpart, supplier data, and engineering calculations. The method(s) used shall be documented in the monitoring plan required under paragraph (g) of this section. However, the use of best available methods under paragraph (f) of this section will not be approved beyond December 31, 2015. Therefore, it is important to ensure that the monitoring plan for compressor vents routed to flare complies with the specifications and requirements outlined in Subpart W, and that any best available methods used are documented accordingly.

question: Do dehydrators which are used to dry a liquid stream meet the definition of dehydrator?
answer: Yes, dehydrators used to dry a liquid stream meet the definition of dehydrator. They are designed to remove water vapor from the input stream using a liquid absorbent such as desiccant or glycol. The process involves the absorption or adsorption of water from the wet gas, which aligns with the definition of a dehydrator as per the provided information. Therefore, based on the text analysis, dehydrators used to dry a liquid stream meet the definition of dehydrator.

question: The emission methods for dehydrator vents with daily throughputs less than 0.4 MMscfd in the preamble (use flow rate of wet NG and EF) contradict the requirements in the rule (use dehydrator count and EF).
answer: The emission methods for dehydrator vents with daily throughputs less than 0.4 MMscfd in the preamble contradict the requirements in the rule. The preamble suggests using flow rate of wet natural gas and emission factor (EF), while the rule requires using dehydrator count and EF. This discrepancy needs to be addressed to ensure consistency in the emission calculation methods for dehydrator vents with lower daily throughputs.

truth: Reporters with dehydrators with annual average daily throughputs less than 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day (MMscfd) must count the total number of such dehydrators and apply an emission factors, as provided in §98.233(e)(2) and Equation W-5, to estimate emissions.  Where inconsistencies occur, rule language supersedes preamble language.

question: For onshore petroleum and natural gas facility dehydrator vents at glycol dehydrators with throughputs less than 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day, can GRI-GLYCalc be used instead of Method 2 in §98.233(e)(2)?
answer: Yes, GRI-GLYCalc can be used instead of Method 2 in §98.233(e)(2) for onshore petroleum and natural gas facility dehydrator vents at glycol dehydrators with throughputs less than 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day, as confirmed by text analysis. There is no conflicting information from table or formula analysis, so the conclusion is supported by all sources.

question: Under §98.233(e)(1), emissions must be calculated from dehydrator vents with throughput greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day.  Is this throughput specific to vent throughput or dehydrator throughput?
answer: The throughput specified in §98.233(e)(1) refers to the vent throughput and not the dehydrator throughput. Therefore, emissions must be calculated from dehydrator vents with a throughput greater than or equal to 0.4 million standard cubic feet per day.

answer: Yes, for Equation W-21, Flare Emissions, when calculating the number of carbon atoms (Rj) for hydrocarbons with more than 5 carbons, the value of 5 should be used.

question: Are flare emissions included in the 98.2(a)(3)(iii) combined emissions from all stationary fuel combustion sources when determining applicability for Subpart W per §98.231(a)?
answer: Yes, flare emissions are included in the 98.2(a)(3)(iii) combined emissions from all stationary fuel combustion sources when determining applicability for Subpart W per §98.231(a). This is based on the methodology specified in §§ 98.253(b)(1) through (b)(3), which outlines the calculation of CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from flares. Additionally, the emissions from flares that burn blast furnace gas or coke oven gas are accounted for in the overall assessment of emissions from stationary fuel combustion sources.

truth: However, for the 2011 reporting year onwards, you must include flare stack emissions in the applicability determination, as flares are included under subpart W.Â  To determine facility applicability, you must determine if you meet the requirements of Â§98.2(a)(1), (a)(2) or (a)(3).Â  Based on the information provided EPA assumes you meet the definition of the source category for subpart W and are only subject to reporting for subparts C and W.

question: Emissions from flares are specifically excluded under 98.232(e) but methods for these emissions are provided in 98.233. Can you clarify which section of the rule is the correct guiding action?
answer: The correct guiding action for emissions from flares that burn blast furnace gas or coke oven gas is to follow the procedures outlined in § 98.253(b)(1) of subpart Y (Petroleum Refineries) of this part. Additionally, the alternatives set forth in § 98.233(k)(5) should be used to calculate the emissions in metric tons of CH4 resulting from flaring gas. Furthermore, the annual N2O emissions in metric tons and annual CO2 emissions in metric tons from atmospheric tanks that controlled emissions with flares must be reported as per the requirements specified in the respective sections. Therefore, the correct guiding action for emissions from flares is to follow the procedures outlined in § 98.253(b)(1) and § 98.233(k)(5) while ensuring compliance with the reporting requirements for N2O and CO2 emissions from atmospheric tanks controlled by flares.

truth: Under §98.232(e), emissions from flare stacks are not required to be reported as a separate emission source for onshore natural gas transmission compression facilities.  However, this does not exclude the reporting of flared emissions from the other emission sources listed in §98.232(e) if they are routed to a flare.  The flare source type in §98.233(n) covers only emissions that are not reported in association with any of the other source types in §98.233; see §98.233(n)(10).  For example, if transmission storage tank emissions are going to a flare, then the rule requires the adjustment of transmission storage tank emissions sent to flare per §98.233(k)(4).  The flared transmission storage tank emissions, however, have to be reported as transmission storage tank emissions under §98.236(c)(9).

The answer also correctly mentions the reporting requirements for N2O and CO2 emissions from atmospheric tanks controlled by flares. However, the answer does not provide any additional information beyond what is asked in the question.

question: Does a simple open pipe with no flare tip count as a flare under 98.233 (n ) in Subpart W?
answer: Yes, a simple open pipe with no flare tip does count as a flare under 98.233 (n) in Subpart W.

truth: 40 CFR § 98.238 defines a flare as “…a combustion device, whether at ground level or elevated, that uses an open or closed flame to combust waste gases without energy recovery.”  An open pipe without combustion would not be considered a flare, but any hydrocarbon releases through it would be considered “vented emissions” under §98.238, which includes “process designed flow to the atmosphere through seals or vent pipes.”

question: Under Subpart W, under both the onshore production and gas processing source categories, are we required to report emissions from all flares at the gas processing facility or on or associated with a well pad, including emergency flares?
answer: Yes, under Subpart W, both the onshore production and gas processing source categories are required to report emissions from all flares at the gas processing facility or on or associated with a well pad, including emergency flares. This requirement is outlined in the text analysis result, which states that the emissions from such flares are required to be reported under subpart W of this part.

truth: Yes, emergency flares are covered under the general category of flares.  For reporting purposes, in the final rule, EPA reduced the burden associated with the flare monitoring and reporting requirements by allowing the use of engineering calculations based on process knowledge, company records, and best available data for estimating flow volumes and gas compositions.
